we're very laid back I think we're too

it's all in vain yeah New Zealand's

those are words that were just never had

before Jim Baker Wilson thank you so

now of course a lot of people still

a day after the fact early I was

there's a sense of still being stunned
that this has happened here in our city

it's is that people are still in shock
over what has happened and I think as
the initial incident wears off it's
going to take a while for people to
actually come to terms that this has
happened here in Christchurch
in New Zealand and in terms of readiness
you said you've been working with your

there's a real concern obviously that
with so many people dead and in Muslim

Christchurch can deal with this that is
very challenging for us I've been told
it will probably take four days to

be a problem so we're gonna have to work
with the community and find a way

don't know hopefully tomorrow morning
we'll have some more answers and we'll
just have to see how that plays out and
do you feel like you've got enough
resources are more being sent we have
we're pulling in resources from around
the country I mean the one advantage
we've had in ways having been through
the earthquakes we've been through this
I mean the medical staff have been
through this before they operate at a

sexton's for the the burial services
they need to be brought in so it will be
asking for help where we need it as you
mentioned
it's not the first time Christchurch has
faced tragedy it's had to deal with
these awful earthquakes in the past the
last they're being 2012 which was
devastating for this community so in
comparison how do you think the
communities dealing with this now
compared to what's happened prior to
this is this the same sort of feeling or
is there sense that actually there's a
lot of you know discomfort and and
concern around this issue I think
probably a mixture I think there's a
weariness or in terms of the earthquake
recovery we had just got to the point
where we just reopened our town hall
eight years after the earthquake a new
Central City Library felt like things
were getting back to normal and then for
this to happen and for children to be in
lockdown at school so that whole sort of
trauma again parents stuck in their
offices or civic buildings it's kind of
reliving that so the mental health issue
which has already had a long tail from
the earthquakes is is of concern but I
think this is also this is this is not a
natural disaster this is a man-made
disaster a domestic terror attack in our
own town so it's going to be quite
difficult for people to actually come to
terms with that and I think as we start
to see and learn more names and put
faces to those and to bury people I
think they will have a bigger impact on
the wider community you were saying that
your your part Muslim yourself and
you've lived here in Christchurch for
many many years so is there a sense that
your community is feeling incredibly you
know uncomfortable unsafe because of
this I think now there's there's
probably some concerns but actually my
sense is that the Islamic community has
still has faith in in new zealand being
a safe place but we have to address some
of the issues around radicalization and
the you know what has led to this attack
but generally the communities have felt
safe even as a general increasing tone
of Islamophobia globally I mean that has
spilled over into New Zealand there's no
doubt about that but in general people
didn't have a lot of concerns you'd go
to Friday prayers no one really thought
too much about it
that was Christchurch City Councilor F
Mong ji speaking to me earlier
now of course as you can imagine it's
the day after the fact many residents
here in Christchurch still very much
coming to terms with this but as you

able to to get through this you know it
is a city that has endured tragedies
like the devastating earthquake about
eight years ago as well so they're
rebuilding they know they can get past
this but at the moment there's a real
sense of you know how could this happen
in our homes how could it happen in our
community how could it happen in New
Zealand where such things are just
unheard of okay Sharon Gao thank you
very much
